of this be set by the mayor and city council 15  warrants and variances  there shall be two levels of approval for deviation from the requirements of this warrants and variances for deviations not designated in this being permitted by warrant permitted by variance or forbidden whether such a deviation requires a warrant or a variance or is forbidden shall be determined by the planning commission the planning commission may from time to time issue guidance to the crc concerning which deviations may be warranted and which require variance with approval of the city attorney for such guidance  a warrant is a ruling that would permit a practice that is not consistent with a specific provision of this is justified by its intent  the crc shall have the authority to administratively approve or disapprove a request for a warrant  a variance is any ruling that permits a deviation which is not warrantable but is in harmony with the overall intent of the light of unique conditions of a site variances from the requirements of this be granted only in accordance with the following procedure a an application for a smartcode variance shall be submitted to the planning official b the planning official shall refer the application for smartcode variance to the city attorney to the board of zoning appeals and to the planning commission c the planning official shall determine in conjunction with the office of the city attorney whether the requested smartcode variance is barred by this shall notify the zoning board and the planning commission of their finding either the planning official or the city attorney shall certify that the variance is prohibited if they so find and shall notify the applicant that the request for variance is denied if the variance request is so denied because it is certified to be barred or prohibited by this the denial may be appealed directly to the circuit court as provided by state law d if the variance is not certified as barred or prohibited by this fourteen 14 days after it is submitted to the planning official the planning office shall schedule a hearing before the zoning board of the application for variance the zoning board shall determine whether the applicant has demonstrated that a variance is justified by showing that 1 special conditions exist peculiar to the land or structure involved but not to others in the same zoning classification which preclude the propertys meeting the requirements of this   2 such special conditions are not the result of actions of the applicant  3 an unnecessary hardship is created by the peculiar and unusual physical character of the property  4 a literal interpretation of the provisions of this deprive the applicant of rights enjoyed by other property owners in the same district  and 5 granting the variance will not bestow any special privilege on the applicant that is denied to other property owners in the identical zoning classification e if the zoning board determines as above that the smartcode variance is justified the planning official shall schedule a hearing of the application for variance before the planning commission which shall then determine whether the granting of the variance as proposed would be injurious to the public welfare or detrimental to the welfare of the community or contrary to the requirements of the comprehensive plan and shall determine whether some lesser variance rezoning or other solution could mitigate the hardship while preserving the public and community welfare and fulfilling the intent of this if the smartcode variance is not certified by the planning official or city attorney to be barred or prohibited see provision c above and if the zoning board finds that the requested variance is justified see provision d above and if the planning commission approves the variance according to the conditions of provision e above or approves only a lesser or modified variance from that requested then the requested variance or the approved lesser or modified variance as the case may be shall be granted failure of the variance application to win approval in any of the above required processes shall constitute denial of the variance g denial of a requested smartcode variance by the zoning board or by the planning commission is appealable to the mayor and city council and if denied by the mayor and city council is appealable to the circuit court as provided by state law  a request for a variance shall not subject the entire application to public hearing but only that portion necessary to rule on the issue under consideration a request from the crc to the planning commission for a ruling about the warrantability of a deviation shall only subject that portion of the application necessary for such a ruling to examination by the planning commission  the following standards and requirements shall not be available for warrants or variances a the allocation ratios of each transect zone b the maximum dimensions of traffic lanes c the required provision of rear alleys and rear lanes d the minimum residential densities e the permission to build ancillary dwelling units f the requirements on the specific location of any required parking spaces g the prohibition of culdesacs and unconnected thoroughfares in community plans where no physical site feature requires such 16  incentives  to encourage the use of this the following incentives shall be granted to the extent authorized by state law a applications submitted under this be handled process as described herein and in compliance with state law b applications submitted under this be processed with priority over others under the existing local codes with prior filing dates c review fees may be waived or reduced in accordance with the provisions of the adopting ordinance or other schedule of fees adopted by the mayor and city council d density may be increased by density transfer consistent with the provisions of this the city shall accept for dedication and maintain those internal thoroughfares that connect to adjacent sites and any publicly dedicated service alleys or service lanes included in an approved new community plan or infill plan 17  miscellaneous procedures  affordable housing affordable housing requirements in this be managed in part following procedures 1 approved affordable housing providers the planning official in conjunction with the office of the city attorney shall designate create and maintain a publicly available list of approved affordable housing providers aahps in order to be so designated and included on this list an organization shall meet the following requirements a the organization shall be recognized by the united states department of treasurys internal revenue service as a taxexempt nonprofit organization b the organizations stated purpose as set forth in its charter shall include increasing the provision of affordable housing within all or part of the city of gulfport ms c the organization agrees it will certify to the city as affordable housing units only properties within its control which are compliant with the terms of d if the organization is a community land trust the city attorney and the planning official shall have approved the organizations deed restriction terms and buyer qualification requirements as being sufficient in combination with the organizations land lease policy to reasonably maintain the likelihood of affordability of the unit for at least 30 years and the organization shall agree to sell certified affordable housing units provided as part of any agreement with the city only to buyers qualified according to the requirements of such agreement for the first five years after creation of such housing units thereafter sale may be to any buyer qualified according to the organizations usual policy e if the organization is an affordable housing trust city attorney and the planning official shall have approved the organizations operating policies and the organization shall have agreed to annually report the compliance of every certified affordable housing unit it provides as part of any agreement with the city with the rent and the resident qualification requirements of such agreements for a period of at least 30 years or to donate the property to another approved affordable housing provider if the organization fails to maintain the required affordability on any certified unit for a total of more than 8 months in any ten year period within that 30 year term of certification f the organization shall submit an application to the planning office attesting to its satisfaction of these requirements and providing such other reasonable information as shall be deemed relevant by the planning official and city attorney g the planning official or city attorney shall not have previously removed the organization from the list of approved affordable housing providers unless whatever conditions which led to the removal of such organization shall have been addressed to the satisfaction of both the city attorney and the planning official 2 probation and removal the planning official shall regularly inspect the list of approved affordable housing providers shall determine a probationary period for any organization added to the list and for any organization which has failed to meet the terms of its agreements with the city in a timely manner an aahp may be required to forfeit any properties acquired during its probation to another aahp or to a public housing authority at the citys demand the planning official and city attorney shall rescind the designation of aahp and remove from the list of approved affordable housing providers any organization which has misrepresented its compliance with agreements made with the city for provision of certified affordable housing or which the planning official and city attorney agree has failed to abide by such agreements in good faith or to significantly correct such failures within a period of one year from the date on which the city has notified the organization of such failures 3 affordable housing agreements the city may enter into an affordable housing agreement with an aahp or with a public housing authority in conjunction with a developer land owner or builder for the creation of a specified number of certified affordable housing units as part of a requirement for increase of allowed density for a new community transfer in accordance with or as part of a density bonus program in accordance with no aahp shall be required to enter into any such an agreement in order to retain its status as an aahp the planning official shall keep a record of all certified affordable housing units created as part of affordable housing agreements and any such unit may be counted as part of at most one affordable housing agreement the responsibility of the aahp or public housing authority in such an agreement with the city shall be to certify the management for affordability of the units according to 4 below  production of such units shall be the responsibility of the developer land owner or builder with the exception that in a case where the aahp guarantees production of such certified affordable housing units with preexisting units not part of any previous affordable housing agreement owned or controlled by the aahp in such case the aahp shall be held responsible for production of the required units and after three years from the date of the agreement if any required units remain unbuilt the planning official shall claim the number of unbuilt units from those offered by the aahp as guarantee as part of the affordable housing agreement and shall record such units as having been part of the original agreement and such units shall not be eligible for use as part of any such future agreement 4 certification of affordable housing units a certified affordable housing unit is defined to be an independent residential housing unit certified to the city by an aahp or public housing authority to be under the control or ownership of the aahp or the public housing authority and to satisfy the following requirements a the unit shall be managed in order to assure continuing affordability for at least 30 years from the date of certification b if the unit is to be sold the certifying aahp shall be a community land trust and the first buyer of the unit shall be incomequalified to purchase affordable housing with gross household income of no more than either of 80% of area median income or of 100% of area median income as specified in the certification for a household of size suitable for the unit in question c if the unit is to be sold the purchase cost for the first sale of the unit including mortgage amortization taxes insurance and condominium or association fees if any shall constitute no greater than 30% of either of 80% of area median income or of 100% of area median income as specified in the certification d if the unit is to be rented the certifier shall be an affordable housing trust with aahp status or shall be a public housing authority  and the lessee shall be incomequalified annually to rent affordable housing with gross household income of no more than either of 80% of area median income or of 100% of area median income as specified in the certification for a household of size suitable for the unit in question e if the unit is to be rented the lease price for the unit shall constitute no more than 30% of either of 80% of area median income or of 100% of area median income as specified in the certification f a certified unit may at any time during the 30year term of the certification be transferred to another aahp for continued management subject to the affordability requirements of the original certification a rental unit held or transferred to a community land trust with aahp status may be sold at any time subject to the original buyerqualification and affordability requirements of the original certification g a certified affordable housing unit within a designated unbundled parking area on the applicable official community plan may include an offer of a single parking space for lease at an annual cost of 3% of either of 80% of area median income or of 100% of area median income as specified in the certification  density bonuses density bonuses shall be managed by the following procedures 1 certificates of density bonus shall be issued by the planning official in conjunction with the office of the city attorney to a developer builder or property owner having met the requirements of some density bonus program specified by this   each such certificate shall be uniquely identified shall indicate the specific lot or parcel the bonus was generated under what program the bonus was generated the number of equivalent housing units awarded for the bonus whether the bonus is transferable to a site other than the one from which it was generated and shall specifically identify the fulfilled requirements of the density bonus program for which the bonus has been issued and shall specify the date of expiration of such certificate 2 density bonuses shall be valid for no more than ten years from date of issue within that period proof of density bonus shall be submitted with any application which makes use of such bonus no less than onehalf unit of a density bonus may be redeemed at one time the planning office shall keep records of all redeemed density bonuses and of the lots and parcels on which the bonus is redeemed and shall check each bonus certificate submitted for redemption against the list of previously redeemed bonuses each fractional or whole redemption shall be recorded permanently on the density bonus certificate 3 the planning official shall keep a record of all issued density bonuses including indication of status as to redemption lots and parcels where the bonuses were redeemed and any other facts necessary to the seamless administration of the density bonus programs described in this planning official shall annually compile a list of density bonuses issued and of structures constructed during the year with density bonuses including tax parcel numbers and street addresses and shall make such list available publicly 4 a density bonus shall not attach permanently to a lot or parcel a density bonus certificate may only be redeemed before its expiration for the permitting of a structure consistent with the requirements of the original density bonus program any structure completed using a density bonus shall not be considered nonconforming with the smartcode and the official community plan if it is otherwise compliant and a certificate of smartcode compliance may be issued for the structure such a structure may be added to or modified in function however if the function volume associated with such a structure is increased after the expiration of the density bonus on which its original construction depended that density bonus may not be counted for the purpose of figuring the compliance of the structure with the density requirements of this the increase in function volume 5 density bonuses shall be issued only after completion of all the requirements specified in the awarding density bonus program however in the case of density bonus programs requiring construction of affordable housing the bonus may be issued before completion of the required housing units under one or more of the following conditions a all incomplete certified affordable housing units required for the density bonus award are guaranteed by preexisting certified affordable housing units pledged and held by an aahp which is party to the corresponding affordable housing agreement with the city  and the land required for the required new units has been secured and is in possession of the aahp the units acting as guarantee may not have been produced in fulfillment of any affordable housing agreement with the city and may not be included as guarantee units in any other incomplete affordable housing agreement during the period during which such units act as guarantee guarantee units need not be located in accordance with the requirements of the affordable housing agreement for which they act as guarantee nor do they in any way lessen the requirement for production of units required by the affordable housing agreement in the event that the required certified affordable housing units have not been completed within three 3 years of the initial date of the affordable housing agreement the planning official shall record the pledged guarantee units as fulfilling the aahps requirement for certification of the unfinished units but the developer builder or land owner shall nevertheless be obligated to complete the construction of the unfinished units b developer builder or land owner agrees in writing that no certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any structure depending in whole or in part on the awarded density bonus until all required certified affordable housing units have either been completed inspected and received certificates of occupancy or all incomplete such units are guaranteed by preexisting certified affordable housing units pledged by an aahp land required for construction of the required units in the required locations shall be in possession of the aahp before any bonus may be awarded developer builder or land owner further agrees that until such certificate of occupancy is issued the structures shall remain unoccupied and in violation of zoning requirements  density transfers attachment and vacation of density rights shall be managed according to the following provisions 1 sending and receiving areas density transfer sending areas shall be determined by official community plans and by the sector plan for the city if one has been adopted in compliance with one of the density transfer programs described in this transfer receiving areas shall be determined by official community plans and by the sector plan for the city if one has been adopted 2 transaction types and procedures density transfer transactions shall be conducted according to the specific type of transaction a buildingscale density transfer transactions shall require the vacation of density rights for the density donor lot or parcel according the requirements of 3 below and shall additionally require the attachment of the detached density allowance from the donor to the density recipient lot or parcel according to the requirements of 4 below b communityscale density transfer transactions shall require the vacation of density rights from a density donor lot or parcel according to the requirements of 3 below and shall additionally require the disbursement of the extinguished density allowance throughout a new community plan in accordance with c alternatively the density rights extracted from a density donor in a density transfer transaction may be represented by a certificate of detached density rights prepared by the planning official in conjunction with the office of the city attorney in accordance with the requirements of 5 below such a certificate may then be used at any later date to effectively replace the density donor site in a density transfer transaction the extracted density rights being transferred from the certificate to the density recipient site 3 vacation of density rights when density rights are extracted from a donor lot or parcel as part of a density transfer the density rights shall be permanently vacated from such lot or parcel according to the following procedure a application for density extraction shall be submitted to the planning office by the owner of the density donor property along with a warranty deed and such additional documentation as the planning official shall deem necessary the planning office shall determine the eligibility of the donor property for the density transfer by determining whether the property lies within a sending area designated by an official community plan or sector plan whether the property meets the requirements of the designating plan for the sending area and whether the density rights have previously been extracted from the property if the donor property is designated as part of a linked sending group of lots or parcels the planning office shall determine that no other property within the linked sending group has already had its density rights vacated b the planning office shall determine the byright density allowance of the lot or parcel or the effective density allowance of the lot or parcel if it is part of an o2 sector sending area for this purpose the planning office may require that the property owner submit a survey of the lot or parcel c if the donor property has been found to be eligible for density transfer the planning official may issue a notice of intent to extract density rights to the property owner acknowledging the eligibility specifying the byright or effective density allowance of the property and describing requirements for completing the extraction including the removal of any structures which would be nonconforming after the completion of the density extraction d for a donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated conservation density transfer sending area density rights shall be extinguished on the donor property by the owners granting of a perpetual conservation easement to an approved conservation trust by deed restriction the deed restriction shall prohibit any structures on the lot or parcel public access requirements shall be as specified by the designating community or sector plan  public access shall not be required if unspecified by the designation plan the deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the conservation density transfer program in articles 2 4 and 5 and shall be of a form which has been approved by the city attorney e for a donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated civic space density transfer sending area density rights shall be extinguished on the donor property by the owners granting of a perpetual conservation easement to an approved conservation trust by deed restriction the deed restriction may permit a single structure for public restroom facilities but shall otherwise prohibit all structures on the lot or parcel the deed restriction shall explicitly permit unlimited public access the deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the civic space density transfer program in articles 4 and 5 and shall be of a form which has been approved by the city attorney the lot or parcel may further be dedicated to the city but such dedication shall not be required f for a donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated transit grid reserve density transfer sending area density rights shall be extinguished on the donor property by the owners granting of a perpetual conservation easement to an approved conservation trust by deed restriction the deed restriction shall prohibit construction of any structures on the lot or parcel other than those related to the provision of public transit and shall provide for the future use of the lot by the city for public right of way for any of public transit a pedestrian or bike path or a thoroughfare the deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the transit grid reserve density transfer program in articles 2 4 and 5 and shall be of a form which has been approved by the city attorney if no approved conservation trust can be found which will accept the required deed restriction terms the lot or parcel may be instead dedicated to the city and deed restricted to public transit or public street usage g for a donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated density recovery transfer sending area the required donor area shall be subdivided from the original lot or parcel and dedicated to the city for public use the donor property shall be deed restricted to the use for which the density recovery transfer is granted the deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the density recovery transfer program in articles 4 and 5 and shall be of a form which has been approved by the city attorney h after execution of the required deed restrictions the planning office shall confirm that the restriction has been properly recorded after such confirmation is obtained the planning office shall attach the extracted density rights from the donor property to a density recipient lot or parcel designated by the donor property owner or shall provide to the owner of the donor property a certificate of detached density rights representing the extracted density allowance of the donor property as indicated on the application for density extraction before the transfer is executed or the certificate is issued the planning office shall verify that no structures remain on the donor property i density donor properties shall within one 1 year of having density rights extracted be rezoned by the planning office according to the requirements of the particular density transfer program which designated the sending area of which the donor property is a part the planning office shall keep a record of all donor properties from which density rights have been vacated so that a permanent development ban may be enforced 4 attachment of density rights density rights extracted from a density donor lot or parcel may be immediately transferred to density recipient lots or parcels or may be transferred by way of a certificate of detached density rights the procedure for attachment of density rights depends upon whether the intended recipients are lots or parcels within designated receiving areas of official community plans buildingscale density transfer or entire transect zones which are part of a new community plan communityscale density transfer  in any case the authenticity of the density rights to be transferred whether directly from a sending area or by certificate of detached density rights shall be verified by the planning office a buildingscale density transfer a covenant between the city and the owner of the recipient lot or parcel running with the land shall be executed and recorded specifying the amount and origin of the transferred density rights and committing the city to recognize the addition of transferred density rights in perpetuity such covenant shall be of a form approved by the city attorney b communityscale density transfer certificates of detached density rights representing the extracted density rights of donors shall be referenced in any new community plan submitted for adoption in which density transfers are utilized the transferred density rights shall be attached by means of increased transect zone density limits in accordance with the density increases for each transect zone resulting from the attachment shall be specified in the new community plan if the developer of the new community so requests the city shall agree to the execution and recording of covenants specifying the increase of density by transfer for each transect zone and committing the city to recognize the addition of such transferred density rights in perpetuity such covenant shall be of a form approved by the city attorney 5 certificates of detached density rights ownership of density rights extracted from a density donor may be retained indefinitely apart from the lot or parcel where they originated in the form of a certificate of detached density rights there shall be no time limit for the redemption of detached density rights but reattachment to a density recipient property shall require the provision of a valid certificate and corroboration in the form of a deed restriction on the original density donor lot or parcel consistent with such certificate certificates of detached density rights shall include at a minimum the following information and requirements a a unique identifier b the date of extraction of density rights from the original donor property c a description uniquely identifying the donor lot or parcel d the area of the donor parcel and the byright or effective density allowance extracted from the parcel signifying the redeemable value of the certificate e the legal name of the owner of the donor lot or parcel at the date of extraction f the written signatures of the city attorney and planning official on the date of extraction g the written signature or mark of the owner of the donor lot or parcel at the date of extraction h a designated block of text providing a description of the transaction including items a above which is authenticated means of publickey encryption by the planning official and the city attorney whose public keys shall be kept on record by the planning office indefinitely issued certificates shall also meet any other requirements deemed reasonable by the city attorney or planning official in order to assure provable authenticity the planning office shall maintain a secure record of all such certificates issued and redeemed and of the associated properties involved in issuance and redemption the planning official and city attorney shall establish and make available for public description procedures for the transfer of ownership of certificates of detached density rights a single certificate of detached density rights may be exchanged for multiple certificates representing in total the density value of the original certificate  the resulting certificates shall be required to include in addition to the above information the authenticated text block from the original certificate 6 approved conservation trusts the planning official shall maintain a publicly available list of approved conservation trusts which meet the requirements of the city for acceptance and enforcement of conservation easements to facilitate enforcement of vacated density rights in order to be designated as an approved conservation trust an organization shall meet the following requirements a the organization shall be recognized by the united states department of treasurys internal revenue service as a taxexempt nonprofit organization b the stated primary purpose of the organization as set forth in its charter shall include conservation of land open space green space or ecology in an area which includes the city of gulfport ms c the organization shall have previously been granted conservation easements to protect land within the state of mississippi d in cases where land owners arrange with the organization for the vacation of density rights for lots or parcels in order to implement density transfers under this the organization shall have agreed to employ deed restrictions in order to secure perpetual conservation easements which the city attorney has approved as sufficiently security the required prohibition of development intended by this vacated density donor properties e the organization has agreed to name the city as a secondary or tertiary enforcer of conservation easements for properties vacated of density rights for the purpose of density transfer under this the mayor and city council have approved the designation of the organization as an approved conservation trust 7 the planning official or the city attorney may establish such other reasonable procedural requirements as they see fit to assure the integrity of the density transfer process and the authenticity of detached density rights certificates 8 the mayor and city council may establish by ordinance a schedule of fees for the administration and processing of density transfers and for the issuance of certificates of detached density rights 18  preexisting and postemergency conditions  damage due to emergency conditions notwithstanding protected habitat d riparian corridors e purchased open space including transfer of special flood hazard areas for the purpose of hazard mitigation f conservation easements g transportation corridors h open space residual to a hamlet cld  reserved  the outline of the preserved open sector shall be considered the rural boundary line rbl 24  o2 reserved open sector  the reserved open sector shall consist of open space that should be but is not yet protected from development as well as open space reserved for future development and inclusion within the urban boundary line  the reserved open sector shall consist of the aggregate of the following categories a undeveloped flood hazard areas including special flood hazard areas not yet transferred to the preserve for the purpose of hazard mitigation b steep slopes and critical habitats c open space to be acquired d riparian corridors to be acquired e buffers to be acquired f legacy woodland marsh and swamp g legacy farmland h legacy viewsheds i future transportation corridors to be acquired  to the extent permitted by applicable law the reserved open sector is a conservation density transfer sending area except for areas intended for use by vehicular and pedestrian traffic and to provide access to lots and open spaces b thoroughfares consist of vehicular lanes and public frontages table 16a the lanes provide traffic and parking capacity and include a variety of widths for parked and for moving vehicles the frontages contribute to the character of the transect zone they include the types of sidewalk curbing planter and street tree c thoroughfares should be designed in context with the urban forms and desired design speeds of the transect zones they pass thoroughfares that pass from one transect zone to another shall adjust their public frontages accordingly or alternatively the transect zone may follow the alignment of the thoroughfare to the depth of one lot retaining a single public frontage throughout its trajectory d within the more rural zones t1 and t2 pedestrian comfort shall be a secondary consideration of the thoroughfare design speeds may be higher than in denser zones and design conflict between vehicular and pedestrian movement shall be generally decided in favor of vehicular mobility e within the more urban transect zones t4  pedestrian comfort shall be a primary consideration of the thoroughfare design speeds shall be lower and design conflict between vehicular and pedestrian movement shall be decided in favor of the pedestrian traffic calming features including but not limited to curb extensions traffic circles and medians should be used to encourage slower traffic speeds and provide for pedestrian safety and comfort f sidewalks and other public space in transect zones t5 and t6 shall be designed using street trees awnings and other shadegenerating devices to provide as nearly continuous shade cover to pedestrians as possible along primary grid streets  thoroughfares a the standards for vehicular lanes shall be as shown in table 3 b the thoroughfare network shall be designed to define blocks not exceeding the size prescribed in table 14e the size shall be measured as the sum of lot frontage lines c all thoroughfares shall terminate at other thoroughfares forming a network internal thoroughfares shall connect wherever possible to those on adjacent sites culdesacs shall be permitted only when necessitated by natural site conditions and when a fully connected thoroughfare plan is impossible  approval by warrant shall be required for certification of such necessity in no case shall a street segment ending in a culdesac have a length greater than 250 feet thoroughfares may terminate in stub streets when such streets act as connections to future phases of the development d enfront a vehicular thoroughfare except that 20% of the lots within each transect zone may enfront a pedestrian passage this fraction may be increased to up to 50% by warrant e thoroughfares along a designated secondary grid  may be exempted from the specified frontage requirements f a bicycle network consisting of trails routes and lanes should be provided throughout as defined in definitions of terms and allocated in table 14e the community bicycle network should be connected to existing or proposed sector networks wherever possible g midblock pedestrian and bicycle paths shall be incorporated in the most pedestrianintensive areas in conjunction with service lanes and service alleys to keep pedestrianroute block face lengths to 400 feet or less h metered curb parking shall be provided wherever possible in t4+ t5 and t6 zones i designated taxi stands shall be provided within rcds j service lanes and alleys shall be paved to driveway standards using pervious materials of a kind readily distinguished from the materials used to pave other thoroughfares  public frontages a public frontages shall be designed as shown in table 4 and length within a pedestrian shed b a designation for mandatory or recommended retail frontage requiring that a building provide a shopfront at sidewalk level along the entire length of the frontage the shopfront shall be no less than 70% glazed in clear glass and provided with an awning gallery or arcade overlapping the sidewalk as generally illustrated in table 7 the first floor shall be confined to retail use depth of the second layer see table 16d c a designation for mandatory or recommended galleryarcade frontage requiring that a building provide a permanent cover over the sidewalk either cantilevered or supported by columns the gallery or arcade frontage may be combined with a retail frontage as shown in table 7 d designation of an outside area for sidewalk retail allowing use in the specified area by pushcart peddlers outdoor restaurants and other open market uses without additional planning commission approval and requiring provision on abutting lots for future leasable openmarket services including associated restaurant space or general retail space with dedicated access to the sidewalk secure storage space within parking structures for pushcarts and coordinated design of public and private frontages within the area to accommodate sidewalk retail usages e a designation of coordinated streetscape frontage requiring that the public and private frontages be coordinated as a single coherent landscape and paving design f specific facade alignment requirements for streets where frontage lines and side lot lines are not orthogonal g a designation of shaded pedestrian way requiring that public and private frontages are coherently planned and planted with a combination of fastgrowing and of more longlived shade trees so arranged in combination with awnings galleries and arbors as to provide nearly continuous shade cover for pedestrians along frontages sidewalks and pedestrian paths so designated h a designation for cross block passages requiring a minimum 8footwide groundlevel pedestrian access be reserved between certain buildings i a designation of terminated vista for a site requiring that any building located at that site be provided with architectural articulation of a type and character that responds to the location as approved by the crc j a designation of buildings of value requiring that such buildings and structures may be altered or demolished only in accordance with preservation standards and protocols established by the planning commission 311  special tree provisions this tree protection measures additional to those of the city of gulfport tree protection provisions of this section shall not amend or repeal any portion part or provision of the gulfport tree protection the event of conflict between the provisions of this section and those of the gulfport tree protection the stricter shall apply  tree protection plan each plan submitted under this include a tree protection site plan showing and describing generally wooded areas of the site and any specimens of 16inch caliper or greater measured at 3 feet above grade on the site the plan shall also show in detail by species and size all existing trees over 12 inches caliper measured at 3 feet above grade within 20 feet of areas where street construction or other improvement is planned clusters of more than 5 such trees within a 15foot radius may be represented in group on such plan however every tree of 16inch caliper measured at 3 feet above grade must be indicated individually such plan shall indicate all trees 12inch caliper or greater which are proposed to be removed the plan shall also similarly depict the area within 100 feet of each tree of 16inch caliper or greater which is to be removed within the construction zone identifying all trees 12inch caliper or greater within that 100foot radius so that potential alternate routes can be evaluated no trees shall be removed before initial plan approval under penalty of replacement according to the stricter requirements of tree removal for construction of streets and improvements shall be allowed only on written notice of smartcode planning approval by the planning commission subject to the following requirements a street layout shall be adjusted whenever possible to preserve larger trees and rare species b no tree over sixteeninch 16 caliper measured 3 feet above grade shall be removed except by warrant c all tree removals shall be subject to the requirements of the city of gulfport tree protection they are stricter than those of this no trees more than 10 feet beyond the planned rightofway for streets and improvements shall be removed except in accordance with the requirements of trees within the blocks and future lots defined by planned streets shall not be removed or damaged except in accordance with the requirements of e every tree 16inch caliper or greater which is removed shall be replaced with minimum 3inch caliper trees of the same species in sufficient number that the total caliper measurement of the replacement trees shall equal or exceed the caliper measurement of the removed tree trees of species described in h are exempt from the replacement requirement f for rare unusual or otherwise valued trees of 12inch caliper or greater but less than 16inch caliper the crc may require replacement with the same species in sizes and numbers to be determined by warrant g all replacement trees shall be planted in planned civic spaces or on lots planned for civic buildings replacement trees may be placed on planned private frontages by warrant subject to approval by warrant where sites are heavily wooded or suitable permanent sites are not available replacement trees may be planted in other community planning areas within the city having official community plans as street trees or in civic spaces with substitution of species to accommodate the requirements of the relevant official community plan approved by warrant h notwithstanding a b c d e and f any trees or scrub of any size of the following species or of species included on a list approved and maintained by the city arborist are deemed undesirable and shall be removed on account of their invasive or otherwise problematic character sabium sebiferum chinese tallow tree popcorn tree cinnamomum camphora camphor tree quercus nigra water oak ligustrum sinense chinese privet  removal of trees contrary to the provisions of this require replacement at the rate of 2 caliper inches of inkind replacement measured at 3 feet above grade for every caliper inch inappropriately removed measured at the top of the residual stump or 3 feet above grade or as estimated by the city arborist with replacement trees of at least 2inch caliper to be adjusted by warrant  it shall be unlawful for any person firm organization or society to violate the provisions of this article the removal or destruction of each protected tree shall constitute a separate offense under this article and said violation or violations if deemed by the city arborist to be willful may in addition to the penalties provided by  be prosecuted and punishable in accordance with of the city of gulfport ordinances  101707 312  procedural requirements  approval process for new community plans the approval process for new community plans shall comprise three parts a informal meetings with the planning official and consolidated review committee leading to preparation of a smartcode development application b submission of smartcode development application for crc review and smartcode planning approval hearing c submission of a completed new community plan for hearing for adoption as an official community plan adoption includes final plat approval and final rezoning  informal meetings with the crc it is recommended that developers and property owners interested in developing a new community begin with informal meetings with the citys planning official and consolidated review committee while strongly recommended for guidance such meetings are not mandatory  smartcode planning approval hearing a in order to qualify for the new community approval process the designated new community planning area shall not be a part of any existing official community plan unless the included portion of the site meets the minimum infill size requirement for the type of proposed community smaller areas subject to an official community plan may be handled by means of infill plans in accordance with b a completed smartcode development application shall be submitted along with required warrant requests for review by the crc during the initial review the crc shall check for compliance with this relevant existing codes and shall respond to the applicant with a review of the application including a list of detected deviations from this including any unmet requirements for warrants and variances if the application including all approved warrants and variances is found acceptable the crc shall notify the applicant of a finding of no objections and shall issue a review to both the applicant and the planning commission summarizing the evaluation describing any concerns and indicating whether any unapproved deviations were found in the application c the applicant may at any time submit a complete smartcode development application to the planning official to schedule a hearing for smartcode planning approval by the planning commission on receipt of a complete and accurate application a crc review of the application shall be provided to the planning commission along with the application within a reasonable period of time  public notice shall be given in accordance with with state law  notice shall be mailed to owners of property within 160 feet of the site  and public hearing before the planning commission shall be scheduled at the public hearing the planning commission may approve or deny the application if denied the planning commission shall provide explanation in writing of the reasons for denial the planning office may rely on a list provided and certified to by an applicant or as shown by the latest tax assessors records of property owners and mailing addresses within 160 feet for mailing purposes notice by publication according to state law shall be mandatory to approval d smartcode development application submission requirements shall be as per shall include such other reasonable requirements as the planning office shall establish e on rejection by the planning commission an applicant may resubmit the application after making changes or may appeal the rejection on resubmission the crc shall only be required to address changes made to the application in its review and the change review and original review shall both be submitted to the planning commission with the application for a second public hearing f on acceptance the planning commission shall notify the applicant in writing of its decision including any conditions of acceptance in the case of conditional acceptance the commission shall also specify changes required the character and extent of required improvements and the amount of the surety bond which will be required in lieu of the completion of required improvements g on acceptance by the planning commission the applicant shall be given 30 days to accept or deny the commissions decision if the applicant accepts the community planning area described in the submitted application shall be designated on the citys official zoning map as a smartcode planning area and the land owner shall be deemed to have elected to exercise the smartcode zoning option once the applicant has agreed in writing to accept the designation the community planning area shall be mandatorily subject to this local codes shall apply within such community planning area only to the extent that they do not conflict with this community plan adoption hearing after completion of the new community plan the applicant may submit the plan with final plat for adoption a a new community plan shall first be submitted for review by crc the crc shall check for compliance of the plan with this request clarifications and respond to applications for warrant the applicant may at any time request a final assessment from the crc on request for hearing the crc shall prepare a final assessment for the planning commission pointing to any questions of compliance detailing any unresolved objections or issuing a finding of no objection a copy of the final assessment shall be provided to the applicant b the applicant may at any time after requesting final assessment from the crc submit the new community plan for adoption hearing public notice shall be given consistent with with state law  owners of property within 160 feet of the site shall be notified by mail and public hearing shall be held before the planning commission planning commission shall review and make recommendation to the mayor and city council for acceptance may refuse approval or may conditionally recommend approval contingent on specific changes if rejected the applicant may appeal to the mayor and city council or may rework and resubmit to the planning commission the planning commission shall communicate its decision in writing along with any reasons for disapproval to the mayor and city council and to the applicant the purposes notice by publication according to state law shall be mandatory to approval c on a recommendation of acceptance by the planning commission the mayor and city council shall approve or disapprove adoption of a new community plan adoption of a new community plan includes acceptance of the final plat and approval of the final rezoning described in the approved community plan d failure transect zone generally face facades of the same zone across thoroughfares 43  community types existing development shall be planned according to the following community types including and assigning to the extent applicable the designations of neighborhood and city center to existing development patterns  neighborhoods tnds traditional neighborhood development neighborhoods shall be urbanized areas of at least 20 acres that are primarily residential a neighborhood shall be based upon a partial or entire standard pedestrian shed the physical center of the neighborhood should be located at an important traffic intersection associated with a civic or commercial institution and the edges of the neighborhood should blend into an adjacent neighborhood or city center without buffer a neighborhood shall meet the requirements for a tnd as set forth in tables 2 and 14  city center rcd or regional center development city centers downtowns shall be urbanized areas of at least 40 acres that are primarily mixed use a city center shall be defined by a long pedestrian shed oriented around an important commercial corridor city centers should be the location of large commercial and retail uses as well as government and other civic institutions of regional importance the edges of a city center should blend into adjacent neighborhoods without buffer a city center shall meet the requirements for an rcd as set forth in tables 2 and 14  special districts sd special districts shall be areas dedicated for certain uses that by virtue of size or function cannot meet the requirements for any transect zone or combination of zones the use of special districts within an existingcommunity plan shall be subject to review and recommendation of the planning commission in the process of preparing an existingcommunity plan 44  density requirements  the community plan shall establish a maximum buildingscale density and an absolute maximum buildingscale density for each of transect zone in the community planning area the maximum buildingscale density multiplied by the area of the lot yields the density allowance for that lot for transect zone t3 the density allowance for lots is always one 1 unit per lot with the exception of cases described in provisions   and  below structures built on a lot shall be limited to a number of equivalent housing units which is less than or equal to the byright density allowance equivalent housing units represent a combination of mixed use space lodging bedrooms and independent residential units according to the following conversation schedule a one independent residential unit constitutes one equivalent housing unit b one thousand square feet of office or retail space constitutes one equivalent housing unit c two lodging bedrooms constitute one equivalent housing unit  density transfer receiving areas  density bonus receiving areas the existingcommunity plan may designate buildingscale areas the byright density allowance may be exceeded for a lot within a designated density transfer receiving area or bonus receiving area on the existingcommunity plan by an amount equal to the acquired density allowance for the lot so long as the sum of byright and acquired density allowances does not exceed the absolute maximum density allowance for that lot a density transfer receiving areas are chosen for their ability to support localized additional density without a net increase of the citys overall density and with lesser ill effects on public welfare and goals of the comprehensive plan than if that density increment had not been transferred b density bonus receiving areas are chosen to minimize the impact of slight increases of density to achieve improved urban structure and other goals benefiting community welfare as set forth in the comprehensive plan and to offset any ill effects of an increase in density with advantages accruing from the density placement or the action which led to the granting of the bonus c density bonuses and transfers notwithstanding in no case may the number of equivalent housing units incorporated into a lot exceed the absolute maximum density allowance for such lot d for lots in t3 zones the absolute maximum density allowance is one 1 equivalent housing unit per lot e acquired density may originate from any density sending area in the city of for the public dedication of a portion of a parcel or lot which has been recommended for public use in the existingcommunity plan as the area of the land to be dedicated is lost to the property owner a density allowance equal to the maximum buildingscale density for the lot multiplied by the area of the portion of land to be dedicated is permanently attached to the remaining lot so that the total density allowance of the lot before and after the dedication is unchanged the following recommendations on the special requirements and options map of the existingcommunity plan entitle a lot to a density recovery transfer should the dedication be executed a through street recommended b service lane recommended c any recommendation accompanied by the designation density recovery transfer applies  density bonuses density bonuses may be generally available throughout a community planning area may be limited to the designated density bonus receiving areas on an existingcommunity plan or tables article 7  definitions of terms this definitions for terms in this are technical in nature or that otherwise may not reflect a common usage of the term if a term is not defined in this then the planning commission shall determine the correct definition of the term definitions absolute maximum buildingscale density a parameter of a transect zone or district which conveys the maximum number of equivalent housing units per unit lotlevel area which can be constructed on lots within the district or zone independent of how the density rights were acquired for each lot in the district the absolute maximum buildingscale density along with the lots area determines the absolute maximum density allowance for the lot see maximum buildingscale density absolute maximum density allowance the maximum number of equivalent housing units which may be constructed on a lot means including by right by density transfer or by density bonus the absolute maximum density allowance is determined by multiplying the appropriate absolute maximum buildingscale density by the area of the lot under no circumstances may a lots density allowance exceed the lots absolute maximum density allowance see also lot density allowance byright density allowance acquired density allowance a number of equivalent housing units which may be constructed on a lot as a result of acquisition of density rights transfer or density bonus the lot density allowance is the sum of the acquired and byright density allowances advisory flood hazard area one of several flood hazard areas which may be identified and regulated by the city of gulfports flood damage prevention the flood damage prevention a detailed description additional height allowance a number of stories beyond the maximum byright height limit for the assigned transect zone which may be constructed on a lot within a density receiving area as a result of obtaining a particular acquired density allowance the relationship between a particular additional height allowance and the acquired density allowance which permits it is determined by the heightdensity breakpoint table of the community plan see also heightdensity breakpoint table unbundled parking must be secured affordable housing agreement a set of written agreements between an applicant for a development the city and an approved affordable housing provider or public housing factor a coefficient greater than or equal to 10 representing the degree to which a single physical parking space may provide needed parking for two distinct functions if freely shared for example a sharing factor of 14 for a pair of functions indicates that ten parking spaces shared between those functions serve as effectively as would seven spaces dedicated to each function in isolation sharing available for unstructured recreation and civic purposes a square is spatially defined by building frontages see table 13 for a more complete description standard pedestrian shed an area roughly circular that is centered on a common destination a pedestrian shed is applied to determine the approximate size of a neighborhood a standard pedestrian shed is 14 mile radius or 1320 feet about the distance of a fiveminute walk at a leisurely pace the standard pedestrian shed is based on the fact that provided with a pedestrian environment most people will walk this distance rather than drive the outline of the shed must be refined according to actual site conditions particularly along thoroughfares sometimes called a walkshed or walkable catchment see pedestrian shed stepback a horizontal offset of a building facade as measured at two different heights the offset must move the facade away from the frontage or lot line it faces with increasing height a stepback requirement may be monolithic as in a requirement for a 24foot stepback at the eighthninth story transition or cumulative as in a requirement for a 24foot stepback between the top of the fourth story and the bottom of the ninth story stoop a private frontage type characterized by a facade aligned close to the frontage line a first story elevated from the sidewalk sufficiently to secure privacy for the windows and typically an exterior stair and landing leading to the entrance story a level within a building defined by a floor and ceiling in most transect zones a story may be no more than 14 feet in height from finished floor to finished ceiling unused vertical space above the height baseline of no more than 4 feet raised basements and attics are not considered stories for the purposes of determining building height see table 8 streamside corridor the zone within which a waterway flows its width to be variably interpreted according to the transect zone street st a local urban thoroughfare of low speed and capacity its public frontage consists of raised curbs drained by inlets and sidewalks separated from the vehicular lanes by a planter and parking on both sides the landscaping consists of regularly placed street trees this type is permitted within the more urban transect zones t4t6 streets and parking map one of the three maps included in an existingcommunity plan or new community plan syn streets and parking plan streetscape the urban element that establishes the major part of the public realm the streetscape is composed of thoroughfares travel lanes for vehicles and bicycles parking lanes for cars and sidewalks or paths for pedestrians as well as the visible private frontages building facades and elevations porches yards fences awnings etc and the amenities of the public frontages street trees and plantings benches streetlights etc streetscreen sometimes called streetwall a freestanding wall built along the frontage line or coplanar with the adjacent facade often for the purpose of masking a parking lot from the thoroughfare streetscreens should be between 4 and 8 feet in height and constructed of a material matching the adjacent building facade the streetscreen may be a hedge or fence by warrant streetscreens shall have openings no larger than is necessary to allow automobile and pedestrian access in addition all streetscreens over 4 feet high shall be 30% permeable or articulated to avoid blank walls a single length of streetscreen along a frontage including any pedestrian and vehicle openings may be no longer than 50 feet maximum substantial modification alterations to a building that are valued at more than 50% of the replacement cost of the entire building if new subzone a zone which shares many of its requirements with one or more other zones the zones are referred to as subzones of a zone which represents the entire class terminated vista a location at the axial conclusion of a thoroughfare a building located at a terminated a community a town center in a hamlet or small tnd may consist of little more than a meeting hall corner store and main civic space a town center for rcd or tod communities may be a substantial downtown commercial area often connected to other town centers by transit townhouse syn rowhouse see rearyard building  trace a feature of a site either natural or resulting from historic usage by man which gives the undeveloped land its character traces include paths roads ponds woods meadows slopes streams and wetlands transect a system of ordering human habitats in a range from the most natural to the most urban the smartcode is based upon six transect zones which describe the physical character of place at any scale according to the density and intensity of land use and urbanism transect zone tzone transect zones are administratively similar to the landuse zones in conventional codes except that in addition to the usual building use density height and setback requirements other elements of the intended habitat are integrated including those of the private lot and building and the enfronting public streetscape the elements are determined by their location on the transect scale the tzones are t1 natural t2 rural t3 suburban t4 general urban t5 urban center and t6 urban core see table 1 transect zone district term used to designate a delineated area which is a physical instance of a transect zone the term is used where it is necessary to distinguish the district from the abstract zone itself transition line a horizontal line spanning the full width of a facade expressed by a material change or by a continuous horizontal articulation such as a cornice or a balcony tree protection site plan site plan for a proposed development showing location of protected trees and trees proposed to be removed the tree protection site plan shall be created in accordance with the special tree provisions 311 and 513 of this a form category determined by function disposition and configuration including size or extent for example there are community types street types civic space types and others see also building type  udc urban design center an organization facade a length of facade is unarticulated at street level if it is devoid of doors windows shopfront glass niches or other ornament and variation intended to keep the interest and attention of
